Gender: Male

Age: 7

MRN: 753394

Diagnosis: Budd-Chiari syndrome

History and Physical:

Doctor:

Hello, how are you today?

Patient's Mother:

Hello,  doctor.  We're  here  for  a  follow-up  regarding  my  son,  Jawad  Hussain.  Hes  7  years  old  and

weighs  16  kg,  standing  at  105  cm.  He  is  from  Gujrat,  and  he  has  two  siblings,  one  of  whom  is

healthy. His birth was by C-section, and theres no known family history of any medical conditions.

Doctor:

Alright,  I  see.  Could  you  please  tell  me  more  about  his  condition  and  any  symptoms  hes  been

experiencing?

Patient's Mother:

Yes, Jawad has been suffering from abdominal distension for the last six months. About six months

ago,  he  developed  this  distension  along  with  some  mild  pain.  We  initially  went  to  a  nearby  clinic,

where  an  ultrasound  showed  hepatomegaly  and  altered  liver  echotexture.  He  was  referred  to

Childrens Hospital, where they did some lab tests and performed an endoscopy. A liver biopsy was

attempted but couldnt be completed due to bleeding concerns. Recently, I noticed two episodes of

blood in his stool, about 2-3 ml of fresh blood after he passed stool, but it was painless, and there

hasnt been any other bleeding elsewhere. He also had high-grade fever with variations throughout

the  day,  especially  at  night,  and  a  dry  cough.  The  symptoms  improved  after  we  started  some

medications prescribed by a local doctor.

 Doctor:

Thank you for explaining. I see that Jawads condition is quite serious. Do you have any history of

complications or hospitalizations?

Patient's Mother:

Yes, he was admitted to Childrens Hospital one month ago and three months ago as well. He has

been  diagnosed  with  hepatic  fibrosis  based  on  an  ultrasound  performed  in  July  2023,  and  there

have been some decompensations like abdominal distension and mild pelvic ascites back in July.

Doctor:

Understood. Lets go ahead and check his current status. During the examination, I observed that his

weight  and  height  are  below  the  25th  and  5th  percentiles,  respectively.  There  was  no  jaundice,

pallor,  or  edema.  His  liver  is  four  fingers  below  the  costal  margin,  and  its  firm  in  consistency.  The

spleen is also palpable, about three fingers below the subcostal margin. His abdomen is distended,

with a prominent abdominal vein. I did not find any tenderness, but his liver and spleen could not be

precisely measured due to the tense abdomen.

Patient's Mother:

Thats correct. He seems to be sleeping a lot lately and doesnt respond well to pain or stimuli. Hes

not very oriented either.

Doctor:

Thank you for that. We will continue monitoring him closely. Ive gone through his recent lab results

and previous tests. His bilirubin is at 1.10, ALT is 16, ALP is 432, albumin is 3.4, INR is 1.17, WBC

count  is  8.14,  hemoglobin  is  11.44,  and  platelets  are  244.  His  Hepatitis  B  surface  antigen  and

anti-HCV tests were negative as of July 2023.

 Patient's Mother:

Yes, we had those tests done, and they came back negative.

Doctor:

Great. As for the endoscopy, the last procedure on 27th July 2023 showed grade 2 varices with no

gastroenteropathy,  and  one  band  was  applied.  The  follow-up  endoscopy  on  12th  October  2023

showed  grade  1  varices  with  moderate  to  severe  gastroenteropathy.  Based  on  the  ultrasound

performed on 15th July 2023, it was noted that his liver was enlarged, measuring 13 cm, with altered

echogenicity. The spleen size was 9 cm. His diagnosis of congenital hepatic fibrosis is confirmed.

Patient's Mother:

Yes, the doctors mentioned congenital hepatic fibrosis as the diagnosis.

Doctor:

For  treatment,  were  currently  prescribing  the  following  medications:  Inderal  10  mg  twice  a  day,

Oss-Pro syrup 5 ml once daily, Cefspan DS syrup 5 ml once daily, A Dew drops two drops daily, and

Indrop D once every 15 days. I have also advised a liver biopsy and shearwave elastography in the

plan. Additionally, well continue surveillance endoscopy and follow-up after three months.

Patient's Mother:

Thank  you,  doctor.  We  will  follow  the  plan  as  suggested.  Is  there  anything  else  we  should  be

concerned about?

Doctor:

Currently,  the  focus  is  on  managing  his  symptoms,  preventing  further  complications  like  variceal

bleeding,  and  closely  monitoring  liver  function.  Well  continue  to  adjust  his  treatment  based  on  his

 response. Please also be mindful of his diet and the medications. Lets plan for a follow-up visit in

three months. If his condition worsens before then, dont hesitate to contact us sooner.

Patient's Mother:

Thank  you  so  much  for  your  care,  doctor.  Well  make  sure  to  follow  up  regularly  and  keep  you

updated.

Follow-Up Visit on 26th February 2024

Doctor:

Hello, how has Jawad been doing since we last saw him?

Patient's Mother:

Hes  been  having  some  issues  with  black,  tarry  stools  again,  and  weve  noticed  that  his  abdominal

distention persists. He has also been sleeping a lot and is still quite irritable.

Doctor:

Lets review his recent tests. His latest endoscopy on 10th February 2024 showed grade 1 varices

with  gastroenteropathy.  He  had  a  follow-up  ultrasound  on  17th  March  2024,  which  showed  mild

hepatomegaly  with  homogeneous  texture.  His  liver  enzymes  are  still  elevated,  and  his  albumin

levels remain low.

Patient's Mother:

Yes,  weve  been  following  the  treatment  regimen,  and  his  symptoms  have  been  somewhat

manageable, but theres still a lot of concern.

Doctor:

 Well  continue  with  the  treatment  plan  as  advised.  Theres  no  change  in  his  medications:  Inderal,

Oss-Pro,  and  other  treatments.  I  would  also  recommend  that  you  follow  up  with  a  specialist  for

further  optimization  of  his  medical  care.  Well  keep  a  close  eye  on  his  liver  function  and  general

well-being.

Patient's Mother:

Understood, doctor. Well keep following up as instructed. Thank you for your ongoing support.

Doctor:

Youre  welcome.  Keep  a  close  watch  on  his  condition  and  reach  out  if  you  notice  any  significant

changes. See you in three months for the next follow-up.

Final Follow-Up on 12th June 2024

Doctor:

Hello, how is Jawad doing today?

Patient's Mother:

Hes  been  struggling  with  his  symptoms,  but  weve  kept  up  with  his  medications.  Hes  been  having

more frequent black stools, and his distended abdomen has caused more discomfort.

Doctor:

Based on his latest examination and lab results, weve confirmed that his liver is still showing signs

of significant strain. The next step is to consider liver transplantation. Well need to work closely with

specialists  for  counseling  and  further  evaluations.  Lets  continue  the  current  medications  and  keep

managing his symptoms as best as we can.

 Patient's Mother:

Were ready to take any necessary steps. Thank you for your continued care.

Doctor:

Well continue to support you and Jawad through this. Lets keep a strong line of communication and

address any issues that arise.

Medications: Cefspan DS syrup 5 ml once daily
A Dew drops two drops daily

altered liver echotexture
enlarged liver measuring 13 cm
spleen size 9 cm

raw_text:
Gender: Male

Age: 41

MRN: 767766

Diagnosis: Chronic viral hepatitis C

History and Physical:

Patient: Hi, Doctor, Im feeling a bit off today.

Doctor: Hello! How are you feeling overall?

Patient: Ive been having some epigastric discomfort and dizziness after meals.

Doctor: Alright, lets go through your details. You had a liver transplant (SP LDLT) due to HCV, HCC,

and DCLD, with the surgery on July 10th, 2024, and you were discharged on July 29th, 2024. You're

currently on POD (post-operative day) 5 months.

Doctor: I see your latest AFP (on November 4th, 2024) is 8.35, which is high. Let's take a look at

your CT scan from the same date.

CT  Scan:  Transplanted  liver  shows  smooth  margins  with  normal  enhancement.  No  focal  lesion.

Patent hepatic vasculature, including both hepatic arteries. Minimal intrahepatic biliary prominence

is  unchanged.  The  large  air-containing  collection  has  almost  fully  resolved  with  a  small  residual

volume along the hepatic cut surface in the right sub-diaphragmatic region, measuring 2 x 5 x 1.2

cm, corresponding to a volume of 6 ml. No other collection or significant findings. Splenomegaly of

13.5 cm is noted without ascites or significant abdominal lymphadenopathy.

Doctor:  Your  wound  looks  healthy  with  no  major  concerns.  Theres  no  active  issue  other  than  the

epigastric discomfort after meals. Your medications and lab results are reviewed, and well continue

with the same doses for tacrolimus and mycophenolate mofetil.

 Doctor:  Id  recommend  a  follow-up  after  3  weeks.  Also,  please  keep  an  eye  on  your  diet,  and  feel

free to contact me if anything changes. If you experience any new symptoms or issues, let me know

immediately.

Patient:  Ive  been  feeling  slightly  better  overall,  but  I  still  have  some  pain  at  the  surgical  site,

especially on the right hypochondrial area. Its been bothering me for the past week.

Doctor: Noted. You were readmitted on August 22nd, 2024, for abdominal distention and pain. A CT

scan  showed  a  large  collection  along  the  cut  surface,  extending  into  the  subhepatic  region  with  a

volume  of  about  512  ml.  An  IR-guided  percutaneous  catheter  was  inserted,  and  the  fluid  culture

came  back  positive  for  Klebsiella  pneumonia.  The  antibiotics  were  adjusted  accordingly.  The

collection  has  since  reduced,  and  a  follow-up  scan  on  September  4th  showed  a  tiny  collection

remaining, measuring about 2.5 x 1.2 x 1.5 cm with a corresponding volume of 2.5 ml.

Doctor: As for your treatment, well continue monitoring, and your latest plan includes:

Discontinuing Septran.

Discontinuing PCT.

Decreasing fluconazole to 50 mg daily.

Continuing with tacrolimus 2.5 mg twice daily and mycophenolate mofetil 500 mg twice daily.

Follow-up in 2 weeks.*

 Patient: What should I be doing to avoid these collections and manage pain?

Doctor: Ensure you are following the prescribed medications, and continue monitoring for any new

symptoms.  A  diet  adjustment  could  help  improve  your  overall  condition.  Ill  also  review  your  CT

scans regularly to check for any changes. Pain management can be managed with Panadol 500 mg

as needed.

Patient: Thanks, Doctor. Ill keep monitoring my condition and follow the treatment plan.

Doctor: Great, please do, and make sure to follow up after 2 weeks for your next appointment. Stay

in touch if you have any concerns before then!

NegativeFindings: no active issue other than epigastric discomfort

ImagingFindings: CT scan shows smooth margins with normal enhancement
minimal intrahepatic biliary prominence unchanged
tiny collection remaining measuring 2.5 x 1.2 x 1.5 cm

VisitTimeline.Event: readmission for abdominal distention and pain

SummaryNarrative.ClinicalCourseProgression: Patient experienced epigastric discomfort and dizziness after meals, with a history of liver transplant due to chronic viral hepatitis C.
SummaryNarrative.DiagnosticJourney: CT scans and lab results were utilized to monitor the patient's condition post-transplant.
SummaryNarrative.TreatmentResponse: Patient's condition improved with adjustments to medications and monitoring of collections.
SummaryNarrative.OngoingConcerns: Patient continues to experience pain at the surgical site and requires follow-up for monitoring.

History and Physical:

Date: 31/10/2024

First Visit to PKLI

Doctor: Good morning. What brings you to the hospital today?

Patient: Good morning, doctor. I've been having pain in my right upper abdomen and jaundice. I've

also lost a lot of weight in the last three months.

Doctor: I see. Can you describe the pain? When did it start?

Patient: The pain started about three months ago. It was sudden and quite severe. Along with that, I

noticed my skin and eyes turning yellow.

Doctor: Have you experienced any other symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting, or fever?

Patient:  No,  just  the  pain,  jaundice,  and  weight  loss.  Ive  lost  around  20  kg  and  my  appetite  has

decreased significantly.

Doctor:  Have  you  ever  had  any  liver-related  complications  before,  such  as  ascites,  variceal

bleeding, or hepatic encephalopathy?

Patient: No, doctor, nothing like that before.

Doctor: Do you have any past medical or surgical history?

Patient: No, I have never had any major illnesses or surgeries.

Doctor: Are you taking any medications at home?

Patient: No, but recently I started taking Paracetamol, Tamsulosin, Spironolactone, Furosemide, and

Pantoprazole.

Doctor: Do you smoke, drink alcohol, or use any drugs?

Patient: No, I dont drink or use drugs.

Doctor: Are you married? What do you do for a living?

 Patient: Yes, I am married. I am retired now.

Doctor: Thank you for sharing this information. Lets do a physical examination.

(Physical Examination Performed)

(cid:9)General Examination: No pallor, jaundice present, no edema.

(cid:9)Gastrointestinal: Abdomen soft, non-tender, bowel sounds audible.

(cid:9)Respiratory & CNS: Normal.

Doctor:  Well  also  need  to  run  some  blood  tests  and  imaging  studies.  Here  are  your  recent  lab

results:

(cid:9)Hemoglobin: 9.2 g/dL

(cid:9)Total Bilirubin: 2.82 mg/dL

(cid:9)ALT/AST: 76/218 U/L

(cid:9)ALP: 103 U/L

(cid:9)Albumin: 1.7 g/dL

(cid:9)Creatinine: 0.87 mg/dL

(cid:9)Na/K: 138/3.95

(cid:9)INR: 1.53

(cid:9)Hepatitis B & C: Negative

Your  imaging  results  show  a  dilated  common  bile  duct  (CBD)  with  a  narrowing  near  the  ampulla,

and signs of ascites.

Doctor: You had two ERCP attempts in August and September, both of which failed. Well need to

do further investigations.

Plan:

(cid:9)Baseline Investigations

(cid:9)CT Scan of Abdomen

(cid:9)MRCP

(cid:9)Start Ciprofloxacin 500 mg BD

(cid:9)Tramadol 100 mg BD, Paracetamol 500 mg TDS

 (cid:9)Reduce Aldactone to 50 mg OD and continue Furosemide 40 mg OD

(cid:9)Follow-up in 4 weeks

Date: 14/11/2024

Follow-Up Visit

Doctor: How are you feeling now?

Patient: The pain is still there, but I feel slightly better. The jaundice has improved a little.

Doctor:  Thats  good  to  hear.  Your  recent  CT  scan  shows  an  ill-defined  hypodense  mass  in  the

ampullary  region,  causing  bile  duct  dilatation.  We  suspect  a  periampullary  tumor.  We  need  to

perform an ERCP with a biopsy to confirm.

Patient: I understand. Will I need surgery?

Doctor:  If  the  disease  is  localized  and  theres  no  metastasis,  surgery  might  be  possible.  Well  refer

you to the hepatobiliary team to discuss further options.

Plan:

(cid:9)Refer to Hepatobiliary Surgery

(cid:9)If surgery not possible, refer to Interventional Radiology for PTBT

(cid:9)Discuss case in MDT (Multidisciplinary Team) meeting

Date: 09/12/2024

Hepatobiliary and Liver Transplant Clinic

Doctor:  Your  case  has  been  reviewed,  and  you  have  a  confirmed  diagnosis  of  a  Periampullary

Tumor. You are a candidate for Whipples procedure.

Patient: What is that?

Doctor: Its a major surgical procedure where part of the pancreas, bile duct, and small intestine are

removed. Its the best treatment for your condition.

Patients Son: What are the risks involved?

Doctor: The mortality risk is around 4-5%, and theres a 10-15% chance of complications. However,

 this is the only definitive treatment.

Patient: I understand. Whats the next step?

Doctor: We will discuss your case in our MDT meeting and then proceed with laparoscopic Whipples

procedure. If there are complications, we may need to convert to open surgery.

Plan:

(cid:9)Proceed with Laparoscopic Whipples Surgery

(cid:9)Explain risks to patient and family

(cid:9)Refer to Financial Screening

DiagnosticConclusions: Dilated common bile duct with narrowing near the ampulla
Ill-defined hypodense mass in the ampullary region

ImagingFindings: Dilated common bile duct
Ill-defined hypodense mass in the ampullary region

VisitTimeline.Summary: Review of CT scan results and discussion of potential surgery.
Confirmed diagnosis of periampullary tumor and discussion of Whipples procedure.

SummaryNarrative.ClinicalCourseProgression: Patient presented with abdominal pain, jaundice, and weight loss.
SummaryNarrative.DiagnosticJourney: Initial tests indicated liver issues, leading to imaging that revealed a mass.
SummaryNarrative.TreatmentResponse: Patient reported slight improvement in jaundice but persistent pain.
SummaryNarrative.OngoingConcerns: Need for surgical intervention and potential complications.

raw_text:
Gender: Female

Age: 13

MRN: 755455

Diagnosis: Budd-Chiari syndrome

History and Physical:

Doctor: Good morning, Laraib. How are you feeling today?

Patient: I'm feeling okay, but I've been having some itching and dryness on my hands. The skin has

been peeling for about three weeks now.

Doctor: I see. Lets talk about your medical history and any issues youve been dealing with. Can you

remind me when you first noticed the jaundice?

Patient: I had abdominal distension back in 2019, which was associated with jaundice. After taking

diuretics, the ascites resolved. But then, a few months later, I developed ascites again, and they had

to do a therapeutic tap. Ive also had multiple endoscopic proceduresabout 12 times.

Doctor:  Thats  correct,  I  see.  And  how  have  you  been  managing  since  then?  Any  other  symptoms

recently?

Patient:  I  haven't  felt  any  severe  pain  or  anything  like  that,  just  mild  headaches  and  weakness

sometimes. Also, my skin has been itchy, and Ive been noticing some dryness and peeling on my

hands.

Doctor: Let's review the treatments we've been providing. Youve had a living donor liver transplant

(LDLT)  on  July  3rd,  2024.  Youve  been  on  a  combination  of  medications,  including  Tacrolimus,

Rivaroxaban, and Mycophenolate. How is the surgical site healing?

 Patient: The scar looks healthy. There's no pain at the surgical site, and it seems to be healing well.

Doctor: Thats good to hear. Well continue with the same medications for now. I see from the latest

Doppler ultrasound on July 18th that there was minimal pleural effusion and mild ascites, which is

being monitored closely. There was also a small fluid pocket in the left subdiaphragmatic region.

Patient:  Yes,  I  noticed  some  fluid  accumulation  in  the  scan,  but  I  havent  felt  any  significant

discomfort from it.

Doctor: That's good. We will continue monitoring that. I noticed the Doppler showed some changes

in  flow  as  well.  The  portal  vein  is  patent  with  antegrade  flow,  and  the  hepatic  veins  are  showing

triphasic flow, which is normal post-transplant.

Patient: So, should I be concerned about the flow changes?

Doctor: No, these are expected post-surgery and part of your recovery. The liver is adjusting well.

Well continue to follow up with Doppler exams to keep an eye on these developments. Regarding

your  medications,  weve  increased  your  Tacrolimus  dose  slightly  and  changed  some  other

medications over time. You were advised not to ride motorbikes or attend school for a while, right?

Patient: Yes, Ive been resting a lot, but Ive been worried about going back to school soon.

Doctor: Given your recovery, were advising that you stay home for another month to rest fully and

avoid strain. Youve been prescribed Mycophenolate and Tacrolimus, and weve adjusted doses for

better liver function.

 Patient: I understand. Ive also had some hair loss recently, which has been worrying me.

Doctor: Hair loss can sometimes happen after surgery and with certain medications like Tacrolimus.

It  should  improve  over  time,  but  well  keep  monitoring  it.  Now,  as  for  the  skin  issuestheres  a

possibility  that  you  have  scabies.  Were  going  to  prescribe  a  special  lotion  to  apply  overnight  for  a

few days.

Patient: Oh, I didnt realize it might be scabies. How do I use the lotion?

Doctor: Youll need to apply Lotrix Lotion (Permethrin 5%) to your body at night for three consecutive

days. This should help clear up the skin irritation.

Patient: Okay, Ill follow those instructions.

Doctor:  Great!  Well  continue  with  your  current  medications  and  labs.  Well  check  in  with  another

Doppler abdomen ultrasound, CMV, and EBV PCR tests soon. Your next follow-up will be in about

three weeks.

Patient: Thank you, doctor. I feel more reassured now. Ill stick to the plan.

Doctor:  You're  doing  well,  Laraib.  Stay  positive,  and  well  see  you  in  a  few  weeks  for  your  next

follow-up.

DiagnosticConclusions: small fluid pocket in left subdiaphragmatic region
portal vein patent with antegrade flow

ImagingFindings: Doppler ultrasound showing minimal pleural effusion and mild ascites

SummaryNarrative.ClinicalCourseProgression: Patient has been managing symptoms post-liver transplant with ongoing monitoring.
SummaryNarrative.DiagnosticJourney: Patient experienced jaundice and ascites leading to multiple interventions.
SummaryNarrative.TreatmentResponse: Surgical site healing well, medications adjusted for liver function.
SummaryNarrative.OngoingConcerns: Patient has concerns about skin issues and hair loss.

raw_text:
Gender: Male

Age: 12

MRN: 770943

Diagnosis: Budd-Chiari syndrome

History and Physical:

Patient: Hello Doctor, Ive come in for my follow-up today.

Doctor: Hello, Husnain. How have you been feeling since our last visit?

Patient:  The  abdominal  pain  has  improved  from  before.  Its  now  intermittent  and  mostly  in  the  left

lumbar region. The pain occurs both before and after meals but resolves on its own.

Doctor: That's good to hear. Have you experienced any other symptoms?

Patient: Ive been sleeping a lot more than usual, but other than that, no major changes. My doctor

had stopped my warfarin about 1.5 months ago. It was prescribed in 2017 and I had been taking it

regularly until Dr. Tariq decided to stop it after I developed ascites.

Doctor: I see. Hows the ascites now?

Patient: The ascites has resolved, thankfully.

Doctor: Thats a relief. Lets go through some of your recent medical history. We know that you were

diagnosed  with  Budd-Chiari  syndrome  based  on  your  previous  CT  triphasic  scan.  How  have  you

been managing with your medications?

Patient: Im still on a few medications. I take Inderal 10 mg twice daily, Evion 250 mg once a day,

 D-Max  drops  3  drops  daily,  Aldactone  25  mg  once  a  day,  and  Folic  Acid  once  a  day.  Im  also  on

Pedia Max drops and Lysovit syrup.

Doctor:  Sounds  like  a  good  routine.  Now,  regarding  your  liver  health,  lets  go  over  the  latest

investigations. On your last visit, your bilirubin was at 1.3, ALT at 58, and AST at 42. Your INR was

slightly elevated at 1.4, which we should keep an eye on. Your platelet count is within normal limits,

though, and your WBC count is 3.8. I see your protein C was low at 59% in May. Well monitor that.

Patient: Yes, I remember those results.

Doctor:  For  your  recent  ultrasound,  it  showed  a  mildly  enlarged  liver  with  a  heterogeneous

echotexture  and  some  varices  in  the  hypertrophied  caudate  lobe.  There  was  also  an  echogenic

chronic  thrombus  in  the  main  hepatic  veins,  which  is  consistent  with  the  sequelae  of  Budd-Chiari

syndrome. Your recent CT from June 7th also shows stenosis and occlusion at the confluence of the

right, left, and middle hepatic veins with multiple intrahepatic collaterals draining into the infrahepatic

IVC. You also have some background changes of chronic liver disease and splenomegaly.

Patient: That sounds concerning. Is there anything new we should do?

Doctor: Yes, the findings confirm that we need to continue with your liver disease workup. You are at

stage F4 of fibrosis, as indicated by the shearwave elastography. Well continue monitoring closely.

For now, Id like to continue with your current medications and the follow-up plan.

Patient: Okay, Doctor. Anything else I should know?

Doctor:  We  are  also  planning  an  EGD  tomorrow  to  assess  any  varices  or  gastrointestinal

involvement. During the procedure, we'll check the esophagus and band any varices if necessary.

 Additionally, your blood work will include checking your protein C levels again, as well as screening

for celiac disease, given your family history. Well also recheck your ceruloplasmin and IgG levels, as

we need to rule out autoimmune causes.

Patient: I understand. Is there anything else in the plan?

Doctor: Yes, we will be doing a full baseline workup, including PELD/MELD scoring to evaluate your

liver  function  and  potential  for  a  liver  transplant  in  the  future.  Ill  also  discuss  your  case  with  our

multidisciplinary  team  this  Friday.  Well  monitor  the  progression  closely,  and  I'll  make  sure  all  your

tests and treatments are coordinated.

Patient: Alright, Doctor. Thanks for explaining everything. Ill get ready for the EGD tomorrow.

Doctor: Youre welcome, Husnain. Well make sure everything goes smoothly. See you tomorrow for

the procedure. Lets keep an eye on your condition and adjust as needed.

ActiveSymptoms: intermittent abdominal pain in the left lumbar region

ImagingFindings: mildly enlarged liver with heterogeneous echotexture
varices in the hypertrophied caudate lobe
echogenic chronic thrombus in the main hepatic veins
stenosis and occlusion at the confluence of the right, left, and middle hepatic veins
multiple intrahepatic collaterals draining into the infrahepatic IVC

ScheduledTests: full baseline workup including PELD/MELD scoring

SummaryNarrative.ClinicalCourseProgression: Abdominal pain improved, ascites resolved.
SummaryNarrative.DiagnosticJourney: Diagnosed with Budd-Chiari syndrome based on CT scan.
SummaryNarrative.TreatmentResponse: Currently on multiple medications with ongoing monitoring.
SummaryNarrative.OngoingConcerns: Need to monitor liver function and potential for liver transplant.

raw_text:
Gender: Male

Age: 10

MRN: 795395

Diagnosis: Chronic viral hepatitis C

History and Physical:

Patient (Syed Muhammad Kazeem Abbas Rizvi):

"Doctor, I have been experiencing abdominal pain on and off for the past year. Recently, I have also

been having loose stools and noticed some rectal bleeding."

Doctor:

"Thank  you  for  sharing  that.  I  understand  it  must  be  concerning.  When  did  these  symptoms  start,

and do you have any history of similar issues?"

Patient:

"The pain started about a year ago when I was in the US. I have had loose stools along with rectal

bleeding. Ive recently been diagnosed with HCV."

Doctor:

"I see. Ill need to review your medical history and test results. Have you had any previous medical or

surgical issues?"

Patient:

"I had fits at a very young age, but there is no remarkable surgical history."

Doctor:

"Thank  you  for  sharing  that.  Lets  check  your  current  condition.  Ill  go  over  your  vital  signs  and  lab

results. You mentioned you're taking no medications at the moment, correct?"

 Patient:

"Yes, no medications currently."

Doctor (Reviewing Examination and Lab Results):

"Your  weight  and  height  are  appropriate  for  your  age,  and  there's  no  sign  of  jaundice,  pallor,  or

edema.  On  examination,  your  heart  and  lungs  are  normal,  and  your  gastrointestinal  exam  shows

normal bowel sounds. Let me review your lab results. Your bilirubin is normal at 0.4, but your ALT is

elevated at 89, which is concerning. Your HCV PCR is quite high at 1,090,000 IU/mL."

Doctor:

"It  looks  like  you  have  Hepatitis  C,  based  on  your  test  results.  I  recommend  starting  antiviral

treatment.  I'll  also  prepare  you  for  some  procedures.  We  will  proceed  with  an  EGD  and

colonoscopy, with specific preparations starting on the 16th of August. I will continue your treatment

with Sofosbuvir + Velpatasvir daily."

Patient:

"What about my follow-up? When should I return to the clinic?"

Doctor:

"Your  follow-up  will  be  in  three  months.  Well  repeat  your  liver  function  tests  and  an  abdominal

ultrasound at that time. In the meantime, well follow the colonoscopy preparation instructions, which

include  starting  a  soft  diet  on  the  16th  and  a  liquid-only  diet  by  the  19th.  Ill  also  prescribe  Movcol

sachets for you to take in increasing doses starting from the 16th."

Patient:

"Got it, Doctor. Ill follow those instructions. Whats next after the colonoscopy?"

 Doctor:

"After the colonoscopy, well assess the findings. The biopsies from your duodenum, stomach, and

colon look mostly normal, but there are signs of mild gastritis and chronic active colitis in the colon,

which we'll continue to monitor."

Patient:

"Thanks for explaining everything. Ill see you in a few months."

DiagnosticConclusions: Hepatitis C based on test results
VisitTimeline: Symptoms started about a year ago

SummaryNarrative.ClinicalCourseProgression: Patient has been experiencing abdominal pain, loose stools, and rectal bleeding for the past year.
SummaryNarrative.DiagnosticJourney: Patient was recently diagnosed with HCV and underwent lab tests.
SummaryNarrative.TreatmentResponse: Antiviral treatment recommended and procedures planned.
SummaryNarrative.OngoingConcerns: Monitoring of gastritis and colitis.

raw_text:
Gender: Male

Age: 50

MRN: 779743

Diagnosis: Chronic viral hepatitis C

History and Physical:

Initial Visit (Urology - 11/07/24)

Doctor: Hello! What brings you in today?

Patient: I have been experiencing right flank pain for the past five years.

Doctor: Can you describe the pain?

Patient: It started gradually. It feels like a throbbing pain that radiates to my back.

Doctor: Have you experienced fever or vomiting with the pain?

Patient: No, I havent had fever or vomiting.

Doctor: Does anything make the pain worse?

Patient: No, there are no aggravating factors.

Doctor: Do painkillers help?

Patient: Yes, the pain is relieved by painkillers.

Doctor: Have you noticed any blood in your urine?

Patient: No, I havent.

Doctor: Have you ever passed a stone?

Patient: No.

Doctor: Any previous medical conditions?

Patient: No diabetes, hypertension, ischemic heart disease, asthma, or hepatitis.

Doctor: Are you on any medications?

Patient: Yes, but I dont remember the names. I have also been using homeopathic and hakeemic

medicines for the past two years.

Doctor: Any past surgeries?

Patient: Yes, I had an appendectomy more than 20 years ago and an exploratory laparotomy with a

 lower midline incision 15 years ago.

Doctor: Do you smoke?

Patient: Yes, I have been smoking for over 25 years and also use a huqqa.

Doctor: How is your sleep and food intake?

Patient: Normal.

Doctor: Are you married?

Patient: Yes, and my family is complete.

Doctor: Let's review your investigations. Your CT KUB scan shows bilateral partial staghorn calculi

with a density of 1000 HU. Your DTPA scan shows a GFR of 90 mL/min (Right: 50 mL, Left: 40 mL).

Your creatinine level is 1.

Doctor: Based on these findings, your diagnosis is bilateral nephrolithiasis.

Patient: What is the treatment plan?

Doctor: We will proceed with:

(cid:9)Right-sided PCNL (Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy), followed by left-sided PCNL.

(cid:9)Preoperative lab tests.

(cid:9)Urine culture and sensitivity.

(cid:9)Anesthesia fitness evaluation.

(cid:9)ECG and chest X-ray.

(cid:9)Cardiology and pulmonology consultations.

Follow-up (GI OPD - 26/07/24)

Doctor: You were referred from urology. How have you been feeling?

Patient:  My  symptoms  remain  the  sameright  flank  pain  for  five  years,  throbbing,  radiating  to  my

back, relieved by painkillers.

Doctor: Any changes in your smoking habits?

Patient: No, I still smoke and use huqqa.

Doctor:  I  see  that  your  HCV  status  is  positive,  but  PCR  has  not  been  done  yet.  We  will  need  to

 confirm this with HCV PCR testing.

Doctor:  Regarding  your  kidney  stones,  the  plan  remains  PCNL  surgery,  as  determined  by  the

urology team.

Doctor: We will follow up in four weeks after your test results are available.

Follow-up Visit (28/08/24)

Doctor: How are you feeling today?

Patient: I have pain in my right iliac fossa, which radiates my back and has increased in intensity.

Painkillers help, and there are no aggravating factors.

Doctor:  On  examination,  your  abdomen  is  soft  but  tender  in  the  right  region.  Bowel  sounds  are

audible.

Doctor: Your HCV PCR test from 1/8/24 is detected, confirming active HCV infection.

Doctor: Your urinalysis on 11/07/24 showed glucose and blood. This might indicate diabetes.

Doctor: We will start Sofosbuvir/Velpatasvir (400/100 mg) for three months for HCV treatment.

Doctor: Also, take Nuberol Forte for pain relief.

Doctor: Follow up in six weeks.

Urology OPD Follow-up (30/12/24)

Doctor: How has your pain been?

Patient:  I  have  been  experiencing  bilateral  flank  pain  for  the  past  year,  but  no  LUTS,  fever,  stone

passage, nausea, or vomiting.

Doctor: I see that you completed HCV treatment on 28/10/24.

Doctor: A CT KUB scan from Faisalabad (done a year ago) showed bilateral partial staghorn calculi.

Doctor: We need a fresh CT KUB and some blood tests (CBC, LFTs, PT/INR, APTT).

Doctor: We will also consult gastroenterology and do a urine culture and sensitivity test.

Follow-up Visit (Gastroenterology - 14/02/25)

 Doctor: How have you been?

Patient: I completed my three-month Sofosbuvir/Velpatasvir course for HCV.

Doctor: Any active symptoms?

Patient: No, I feel fine.

Doctor: On examination, you have no jaundice or pallor. Your abdomen is soft and non-tender, and

your heart and lung sounds are normal.

Doctor: Your HCV treatment is completed. We will do HCV PCR testing to confirm viral clearance.

Doctor: Follow-up in two months.

Patient: Thank you, doctor!

Final Diagnosis for Training Purposes:

(cid:9)Bilateral Nephrolithiasis (Partial Staghorn Calculi)

(cid:9)Hepatitis C (Treated with Sofosbuvir/Velpatasvir)

(cid:9)Possible Diabetes (Pending further evaluation)

ImagingFindings: CT KUB scan shows bilateral partial staghorn calculi
Fresh CT KUB needed

NextAppointmentDetails: Follow-up in four weeks after test results

SummaryNarrative.ClinicalCourseProgression: Patient has experienced right flank pain for five years, which has progressed to bilateral flank pain.
SummaryNarrative.DiagnosticJourney: Initial diagnosis of bilateral nephrolithiasis confirmed with imaging; HCV status confirmed with PCR testing.
SummaryNarrative.TreatmentResponse: Patient completed HCV treatment and is currently being monitored for diabetes.
SummaryNarrative.OngoingConcerns: Monitoring for possible diabetes and follow-up on kidney stones.

Gender: Female

Diagnosis: Chronic hepatic failure

History and Physical:

Patient Information:

Name: Sobia Pervaiz

Age: 32 years

Gender: Female

Marital Status: Married, has a child

Residence: Bahrain

Occupation: Housewife

Medical History: Diabetic (most likely Type 1), controlled on Insulin

Social History: No smoking, No alcohol, Post-graduate education

Family History:

Parents: Diabetic, Mother is hypertensive

 Grandmother and Aunt had Breast cancer

Maternal uncle had Blood cancer

Current Medications:

Hormonal medications for conception

Metformin 500mg OD

Insulin

Doctor's Conversation with Patient:

Doctor: Hello, Sobia. What brings you in today?

Patient: I have been feeling nauseous lately.

Doctor:  I  see.  Let  me  ask  you  a  few  questions.  Have  you  experienced  any  significant  weight  loss

recently?

Patient: No, I havent had any weight loss.

Doctor: Have you had any fevers or night sweats?

Patient: No, no fevers or night sweats.

 Doctor: Any physical or cognitive limitations?

Patient: No, I dont have any limitations.

Doctor: Lets go over your investigations. You had an ultrasound, CT scan, and MRI. I see from the

CT scan dated 15th February that it showed multiple bilobar hepatic lesions. Did you experience any

symptoms like jaundice or melena?

Patient: No, I didnt have jaundice or melena.

Doctor: I see your MRI from 6th March shows a large mass centered over segment 4 of 12cm with

washout  and  diffusion  restriction,  suggesting  HCC.  The  biopsy  shows  a  well-differentiated

hepatocellular lesion, which favors hepatic adenoma.

Patient: Yes, Ive been informed about the diagnosis of hepatic adenoma.

Doctor:  Good.  We  are  discussing  surgery  options  for  you.  The  plan  is  to  perform  a  central

hepatectomy  after  Eid.  I  would  like  to  submit  the  CDs  of  your  CT  scan  and  MRI  for  further  MDT

discussion.

Patient: Okay, I understand. I will send the CDs. Is there anything else I need to do?

Doctor: You will meet Mr. Asif for surgery coordination, and we will perform a pre-operative workup.

The  risk  of  mortality  is  around  1-2%,  and  the  morbidity  risk  is  around  10%.  We  will  monitor  your

progress closely.

Follow-Up Visit:

 Doctor: Welcome back, Sobia. How have you been feeling since your last visit?

Patient: I dont have any active complaints. Everything feels normal.

Doctor:  Great  to  hear.  I  see  that  your  CT  scan  from  PKLI,  dated  15th  February,  shows  multifocal

bilobar  arterialized  lesions.  Though  the  biopsy  confirmed  hepatic  adenoma,  the  radiology  report

suggests that fibrolamellar HCC and fibro-nodular hyperplasia remain differential diagnoses.

Patient: Yes, the doctors explained that.

Doctor: For now, the MDT has advised surgery, as the liver mass could be related to either hepatic

adenoma or fibro-nodular hyperplasia. We are proceeding with surgery after Eid.

Patient: Got it. Is there any additional preparation I need to make?

Doctor:  We  will  proceed  with  the  pre-operative  workup  and  fitness  tests.  Please  meet  the

coordinator,  Mr.  Asif,  for  further  details.  And  dont  forget,  the  risks  for  surgery  are  minimal,  but  it's

important to be aware of the potential for complications.

Hepatic Adenoma

Gender: Female

Age: 53

MRN: 897183

Diagnosis: Chronic viral hepatitis C

History and Physical:

First Visit in PKLI

Doctor:

Good morning. How can I assist you today?

Patient:

Ive been having black stool for about a year now. It was intermittent, but for the past three months,

its been continuous.

Doctor:

I see. Have you been hospitalized recently for this issue?

Patient (Attendant):

Yes, she was admitted at Faisalabad Institute of Cardiology for deranged INR. She was referred to

us for an evaluation regarding capsule endoscopy.

Doctor:

Thank you for the information. Do you have any recent blood test reports?

Patient (Attendant):

Her hemoglobin is 6 according to us, but we don't have a recent report available.

Doctor:

Understood. Lets go over your medical history to get a better picture.

Do you have any history of hypertension or other conditions?

Patient:

Yes, I have hypertension. I also had hemorrhoids in the past.

In 2008, I underwent a dual valve replacement, and I was diagnosed with HCV in 2008, but I have

never received treatment for it.

 Ive had episodes of decompensation, including the black stool and hepatic encephalopathy (PSE).

Doctor:

Thank you for sharing that. Lets review your liver-related decompensation history:

(cid:9)Ascites: Any swelling in the abdomen?

Patient: No.

(cid:9)Jaundice: Have you noticed yellowing of your skin or eyes?

Patient: No.

(cid:9)Variceal bleed: Any bleeding from the esophagus or stomach?

Patient: Yes, I required multiple transfusions for variceal bleed.

(cid:9)Hepatic encephalopathy: Have you experienced confusion or changes in mental status?

Patient: Yes, Ive had hepatic encephalopathy before.

Doctor:

Thank you for the details. Now, lets proceed with your past medical and surgical history.

You mentioned hypertension. Any other medical issues?

Patient:

Only the history of HTN.

Doctor:

Any surgeries in the past?

Patient:

Yes, I had a C-section 23 years ago, and I underwent DVR in 2008.

Doctor:

Thank you for sharing. Are there any known allergies?

Patient:

No allergies.

Doctor:

Lets discuss your current medications. What are you taking at the moment?

Patient (Attendant):

 She is currently on the following medications:

(cid:9)Aspirin 75mg once daily (stopped 1 year ago)

(cid:9)Spiromide 40mg once daily

(cid:9)Warfarin 13.75mg (one and a half tablets) once daily

(cid:9)Digoxin 0.25mg once daily

(cid:9)Syrup Ulsanic (two spoons twice daily)

Doctor:

Got it. Now, moving on to your psychosocial history. Are there any concerns about your lifestyle or

limitations?

Patient:

No, no limitations, and no issues with language barriers.

I am married but do not have an occupation.

Doctor:

Thank you for clarifying. Any family history of significant illnesses?

Patient:

Yes, my sister is diabetic.

Doctor:

Now, lets proceed with your physical examination.

On examination:

(cid:9)You are an elderly female, appearing thin and frail.

(cid:9)CNS: Your Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is 15/15, so no signs of acute neurological issues.

(cid:9)GIT: Your abdomen is soft, and there is no tenderness.

Doctor:

We also reviewed your recent investigations:

(cid:9)EGD (Endoscopy): Three times, last on 6-12-24, with small erosions in the duodenal bulb.

(cid:9)Ultrasound Abdomen (6-12-24): Coarse liver with splenomegaly.

Doctor:

 Here are your lab results from 4-12-24:

(cid:9)Hemoglobin: 9.3

(cid:9)TLC: 6.3

(cid:9)Platelets: 177

(cid:9)Sodium: 104

(cid:9)Potassium: 3.97

(cid:9)Chloride: 75.5

(cid:9)Total Bilirubin: 0.97

(cid:9)Direct Bilirubin: 0.58

(cid:9)ALT: 50.8

(cid:9)ALP: 92.4

(cid:9)AFP: 3.57

(cid:9)INR: 2.17

Doctor:

Your  HCV  antibody  test  is  reactive.  Based  on  all  this  information,  I  believe  you  have  HCV-related

decompensated cirrhosis (DCLD), with ongoing issues of black stool and encephalopathy.

Your hypertension is poorly controlled, and your dual valve replacement from 2008 is important to

consider in your treatment.

Doctor:

Regarding your medications, we will continue warfarin due to your DVR, but we need to adjust your

anticoagulation therapy for your upcoming colonoscopy.

Plan:

(cid:9)Admit you for management of melena (black stool), low hemoglobin, and to arrange a colonoscopy.

(cid:9)We will need to switch your anticoagulation therapy temporarily for the procedure.

Doctor:

I have also provided you with patient education on your condition.

 Diagnosis:

(cid:9)HCV-related DCLD

(cid:9)Decompensated with black stool and encephalopathy

(cid:9)Hypertension (poorly controlled)

(cid:9)Dual valve replacement (DVR) in 2008

DiagnosticConclusions: Decompensated with black stool and encephalopathy

Medications: Warfarin 13.75mg (one and a half tablets) once daily

ImagingFindings: Coarse liver with splenomegaly
PathologyFindings: small erosions in the duodenal bulb

SummaryNarrative.DiagnosticJourney: Patient was referred for evaluation after hospitalization for deranged INR.
SummaryNarrative.TreatmentResponse: Patient has not received treatment for HCV.
SummaryNarrative.OngoingConcerns: Management of melena, low hemoglobin, and adjustment of anticoagulation therapy.

raw_text:
Gender: Female

Age: 53

MRN: 839606

Diagnosis: Chronic hepatic failure

History and Physical:

17/10/24 - Diabetic Patient

Doctor: "Good morning! How are you today?"

Patient: "I'm doing okay, but I've been dealing with some health issues lately."

Doctor: "I understand. I see you're a diabetic patient, and you also have HCV positive, right?"

Patient: "Yes, I've been treated for HCV and have been through some medication."

Doctor: "And you've been experiencing some liver complications, like portal hypertension, and you

had an upper GI bleed and ascites. You also mentioned jaundice?"

Patient: "Yes, Ive had all of that, and its been quite challenging."

Doctor: "Okay, based on this, the plan is to continue managing your condition with medications and

a referral to the OPD for further follow-up. You're currently on a good treatment plan."

08/11/2024 - First Visit to Hepatology Clinic, Seen by Dr. Ammara Naveed

Doctor: "Welcome! What brings you in today?"

Patient:  "I  came  in  because  I  had  an  upper  GI  bleed  earlier  this  year  in  February,  and  Id  like  to

discuss a possible liver transplant."

Doctor:  "I  see  you  have  a  history  of  HCV  and  have  achieved  a  sustained  viral  response.  Im  also

noticing  that  youve  had  several  liver  decompensations,  like  ascites  and  jaundice,  and  a  history  of

variceal bleeding. How are you managing these symptoms?"

Patient: "It's been tough. I had variceal bleeding in 2020, and again about six months ago. Ive also

had melena and multiple gastroscopies."

Doctor: "Okay, well plan for further diagnostic steps like gastroscopy and a CT scan to evaluate the

 extent of the damage. We need to review your diuretics, as you're not fully optimized on them yet. I

also  suggest  continuing  your  current  medications  and  adding  a  few  more,  including  lactulose  for

constipation."

Patient: "Got it, Ill follow through with the medications and tests."

12/11/2024 - Follow-up Visit

Doctor: "How have you been since our last visit?"

Patient: "Ive been feeling quite weak and noticed some abdominal distension."

Doctor:  "I  see.  Lets  review  your  situation.  Youre  still  dealing  with  ascites,  jaundice,  and  previous

variceal bleeds, correct?"

Patient: "Yes, thats all still there."

Doctor: "Your CT scan confirms that the HCC lesions are present, with one of them measuring 1.8

cm.  Based  on  this,  the  plan  remains  to  monitor  your  condition  and  consider  a  liver  transplant.  We

will also optimize your diuretic dosage and continue your medications."

Patient: "That makes sense. Whats the next step?"

Doctor: "Well start you on more intensive monitoring, and Ill refer you to a hepatobiliary specialist for

a liver transplant evaluation. We also need to check your blood counts and liver function regularly."

22/11/2024 - Emergency Care for Variceal Bleed

Doctor: "Youve come in for surveillance EGD today. How are you feeling?"

Patient: "Ive had some bleeding from my varices again, though it seems to be under control."

Doctor: "Yes, the EGD shows altered blood and some oozing from the fundal varix. Weve injected

histoacryl, and there are no immediate complications. Im admitting you for monitoring and will start

terlipressin and IV fluids. We might also need a blood transfusion."

Patient: "I understand. Ill stay here for observation."

03/12/2024 - Liver Transplant Referral

 Doctor: "Youre being referred for liver transplant consideration. How are you feeling about this?"

Patient: "Its overwhelming, but I know its necessary."

Doctor:  "Your  current  labs  show  that  your  liver  disease  has  progressed,  and  the  HCC  is  still  a

concern. With your MELD score at 24, we need to move forward with the transplant process. Well

continue  managing  your  symptoms  with  lactulose  and  other  medications.  Also,  well  monitor  your

liver function and blood counts."

Patient: "Im ready for the transplant process, just worried about the donors health."

Doctor: "Weve explained the risks and benefits to both you and your family. The next steps include a

full review and counseling session. Well also discuss donor options."

20/12/2024 - Psychiatry Notes

Doctor:  "How  are  you  coping  with  everything?  Youre  a  potential  liver  transplant  candidate,  and  I

wanted to check in on your mental health."

Patient: "Ive been feeling a bit down, but overall, Im managing."

Doctor: "I see that you have mild depressive symptoms but no major psychiatric concerns. It's good

that you have family support, and youre aware of the risks and process involved in the transplant.

Weve discussed everything, and youre clear on what to expect."

Patient: "Yes, Im aware. Ill stay in touch with my family for support."

30/12/2024 - Follow-up with PSB, Dr. Ahmad Karim

Doctor:  "It  looks  like  your  workup  for  liver  transplant  is  progressing  well.  Youve  had  consultations

with psychiatry, cardiac, and pulmonary teams, all of which came back favorable."

Patient:  "Im  glad  everything  is  going  smoothly.  I  still  have  some  weakness,  and  Ive  been  dealing

with hard stools."

Doctor: "Well increase your lactulose dose to help with constipation and recheck your renal function,

electrolytes, and CBC. After that, we can continue monitoring you for transplant readiness."

Patient: "Thanks, Ill follow the plan and keep in touch with the team."

 30/12/2024 - Gynecology Consultation

Doctor: "Youve been referred for a gynecology consultation as part of your liver transplant workup.

How are you feeling today?"

Patient: "Im okay. Ive had some pelvic issues, but nothing major."

Doctor: "Your ultrasound came back with no major findings. We'll repeat the pelvic ultrasound and

do a pap smear when the kit is available."

Patient: "Alright, I'll wait for the next steps."

DiagnosticConclusions: HCC lesions present, one measuring 1.8 cm

ImagingFindings: CT scan shows HCC lesions

VisitTimeline: 17/10/2024 - Initial visit, discussed health issues and treatment plan
08/11/2024 - First visit to Hepatology Clinic, discussed liver transplant
12/11/2024 - Follow-up visit, CT scan results discussed
30/12/2024 - Follow-up with PSB, progress on transplant workup

SummaryNarrative.ClinicalCourseProgression: Patient has chronic hepatic failure with multiple complications including ascites, jaundice, and variceal bleeding.
SummaryNarrative.DiagnosticJourney: Underwent various diagnostic tests including CT scan and EGD to evaluate liver condition.
SummaryNarrative.TreatmentResponse: Patient is on a treatment plan with medications and is being monitored for liver transplant eligibility.
SummaryNarrative.OngoingConcerns: Patient continues to experience weakness and abdominal distension, with a need for ongoing monitoring and management.

raw_text:
Gender: Female

Age: 5

MRN: 709356

Diagnosis: Budd-Chiari syndrome

History and Physical:

Patient:  Doctor,  my  daughter  has  been  suffering  from  abdominal  distension,  jaundice,  fever,  and

decreased urine output for the last month.

Doctor:  I  see,  thank  you  for  the  details.  Lets  go  over  some  information.  Based  on  the  lab  results

from  September  2022,  I  can  see  a  few  concerning  findings.  Her  GGT  was  54,  albumin  was  3.2,

bilirubin was elevated at 2.4, and ALT was 485. These could be indicative of liver dysfunction. Her

liver enzymesAST, ALT, and ALPare also elevated, which suggests that the liver is under stress.

Patient:  Yes,  shes  been  feeling  unwell  and  has  had  a  lot  of  discomfort.  What  else  did  the  tests

show?

Doctor:  Her  white  blood  cell  count  was  14.1,  which  could  indicate  an  ongoing  infection.  The

hemoglobin is 7.7, which is low, indicating that she is anemic. Also, the INR is 1.3, which suggests a

slight clotting issue. Hepatitis A and C tests were negative, which is good, but her liver function is

still a concern.

Patient: Shes been on some medications, but it doesnt seem like theyve helped much.

Doctor:  I  see  that  shes  currently  taking  Aldactone  and  Lasoride.  These  medications  help  manage

fluid  retention  and  high  blood  pressure  but  might  not  be  addressing  the  underlying  cause  of  her

condition.  The  ultrasound  done  in  September  showed  a  possible  diagnosis  of  veno-occlusive

syndrome,  and  the  CT  scan  further  confirmed  a  Budd-Chiari  syndrome  picture,  which  involves

 hepatic vein obstruction.

Patient: Oh, I see. What does that mean for her?

Doctor: Budd-Chiari syndrome is a serious condition where the blood flow out of the liver is blocked.

This  causes  pressure  to  build  up  in  the  liver,  leading  to  symptoms  like  ascites,  jaundice,  and  an

enlarged  liver.  The  treatment  usually  involves  addressing  the  liver's  function  and  preventing

complications.

Patient: Whats the next step for her?

Doctor: Were planning a virtual clinic tomorrow for further monitoring and would like you to submit

the  CT  scan  CD  for  review.  Well  also  continue  her  medications  as  discussed.  She  needs  a  liver

biopsy and further workup, including an EGD (esophagogastroduodenoscopy) to check for varices.

Follow-up on 10-11-2022:

Patient:  Doctor,  I  brought  my  daughter  in  for  a  follow-up.  Shes  still  dealing  with  abdominal

distension.

Doctor: Thank you for bringing her in. I reviewed her records, and based on her ultrasound, she still

has  hepatomegaly  (enlarged  liver)  and  a  non-homogenous  liver  texture.  Her  condition  has  been

diagnosed as Budd-Chiari syndrome. We will continue her current medications, including Aldactone

and Ibert syrup.

Patient: Shes also been having trouble with her breathing and cough. Does that have anything to do

with her condition?

 Doctor: Yes, the cough could be a sign of fluid buildup in her lungs due to liver dysfunction. Her liver

enlargement is causing pressure, which can lead to fluid accumulating in her abdomen and lungs.

Patient: Whats the plan moving forward?

Doctor: We will need to test for Hepatitis E and A again, and run additional tests like CBC, LFT, and

RFT to monitor her liver and kidney function. Also, were considering giving her vitamin K injections

once  a  week.  Ill  also  recommend  a  course  of  Vermox  syrup  for  three  days  and  will  continue  her

current medications. A follow-up in a month is necessary to assess her progress.

Follow-up on 19-01-2023:

Patient: Doctor, shes still having issues with her abdominal distension. Its been two months now.

Doctor: Ive reviewed her latest lab results from December 2022. Her bilirubin level is now 1.5, which

is better, but still elevated. Her liver enzymes (ALT, AST) have decreased, which is a positive sign.

However, her INR has risen to 1.8, so we need to be cautious about bleeding.

Patient: Should we change her medications?

Doctor:  No  major  changes  to  her  current  regimen  yet,  but  well  increase  the  vitamin  K  to  twice

weekly,  and  shell  continue  with  Maltofer  syrup  for  iron  supplementation.  We  will  also  start  her  on

Inderal for blood pressure management and Lopin EC to help with the liver condition.

Follow-up on 18-09-2024:

 Patient:  Doctor,  shes  been  having  some  new  symptoms.  Shes  been  vomiting  blood  in  the  last  24

hours, and her abdomen is distended.

Doctor:  This  is  concerning.  I  see  that  her  ascites  has  worsened,  and  she  has  developed  Grade  I

encephalopathy, which could indicate worsening liver function. Her labs show a drop in hemoglobin

to  10.3,  which  means  shes  losing  blood.  Her  platelets  are  low,  which  can  also  be  a  sign  of  liver

dysfunction.  The  CT  scan  from  earlier  this  year  still  shows  hepatomegaly  and  obliterated  hepatic

veins.

Patient: Whats the next step? What do we need to do?

Doctor:  We  need  to  admit  her  for  urgent  care,  especially  with  her  encephalopathy  and  bleeding

episodes.  A  liver  transplant  remains  the  definitive  treatment  for  her,  but  we  need  to  optimize  her

condition first. Ill refer her to a specialized children's hospital for further management.

Patient: What else can we do in the meantime?

Doctor:  Continue  the  current  medicationsSpironolactone,  Furosemide,  Vitamin  K,  and  others.  But

the main priority is to stabilize her condition, and once shes medically optimized, well proceed with

the transplant discussion.

Follow-up on 18-11-2024:

Patient: Shes still dealing with some of the same symptoms, like ascites, jaundice, and edema.

Doctor:  Yes,  its  been  a  challenging  time  for  her.  The  EGD  results  show  Grade  IV  varices,  which

means theres a high risk of bleeding. Weve started her on a beta-blocker (Propranolol) to manage

 her portal hypertension and control bleeding risks. Her ascites has worsened, and were continuing

her treatment with Spironolactone and Lasoride.

Patient: Is there anything else we should consider?

Doctor:  Well  continue  with  Vitamin  K  every  15  days,  and  Ive  also  prescribed  Propanolol  and  Ora

drops to manage her liver condition. As always, we need to keep monitoring her closely for any new

symptoms or complications.

Patient: How long until shes stable enough for a transplant?

Doctor: Well need to focus on stabilizing her condition with medical management. Once we get the

results  of  the  financial  screening  and  optimization,  we  can  begin  the  discussion  about  the  liver

transplant.

Plan:

Continue monitoring liver function and manage complications

Liver transplant remains the long-term goal

Follow-up after financial screening

ImagingFindings: ultrasound showing hepatomegaly and non-homogenous liver texture
CT scan showing hepatomegaly and obliterated hepatic veins

SummaryNarrative.ClinicalCourseProgression: The patient's condition has worsened with symptoms of ascites, jaundice, and encephalopathy.
SummaryNarrative.DiagnosticJourney: Multiple tests and imaging have confirmed Budd-Chiari syndrome and related complications.
SummaryNarrative.TreatmentResponse: Medications have been adjusted to manage symptoms and complications.
SummaryNarrative.OngoingConcerns: The need for urgent care and potential liver transplant remains a priority.

raw_text:
Gender: Male

Age: 57

MRN: 762672

Diagnosis: Chronic viral hepatitis C

History and Physical:

Patient Visit: 8 March 2024

Patient: Hello, Doctor. This is my first visit here.

Doctor: Welcome. Let's go over your medical history. Do you have any comorbidities?

Patient:  Yes,  I  have  diabetes  mellitus.  Im  on  insulin,  26  units  in  the  morning.  I  used  to  smoke  but

quit 4 months ago. I don't drink alcohol, and I havent taken any hakeem medications.

Doctor: Alright. Have you had any treatments for Hepatitis C?

Patient:  Yes,  I  was  treated  twice.  The  first  time  was  with  interferons  for  6  months,  about  15  years

ago. The second time, I was treated with DAAs for 6 months, 7-8 years ago. Both times, I achieved

sustained virological response (SVR).

Doctor: Great to hear. Have you had any liver-related issues?

Patient:  Yes,  I  have  chronic  liver  disease  (DCLD)  and  Ive  had  hematemesis  (last  episode  7  years

ago), melena (last episode years ago), ascites, and jaundice.

Doctor: Understood. Lets review your recent tests. You had a USG Abdomen in December 2023. It

showed  coarse  liver  with  splenomegaly,  multiple  dilated  veins  at  the  splenic  hilum,  moderate

ascites, and thick gallbladder sludge with wall edema. How are you feeling?

 Patient: Ive been having RUQ pain, weakness, yellowing of my eyes, and some weight loss.

Doctor: Okay. Your liver function tests (LFTs) in December 2023 showed a total bilirubin of 2.9, ALT

of  110,  AST  of  83,  and  ALP  of  252.  Creatinine  was  0.9.  Your  last  CT  triphasic  HCC  protocol  in

November 2023 showed cirrhotic liver, no arterialized lesions, moderate ascites, and multiple upper

abdominal collateral formations.

Patient: That sounds serious.

Doctor:  It's  important  we  keep  an  eye  on  these  things.  For  now,  we'll  continue  with  your  current

medications and follow up in 2 weeks. Also, I advise you to eat smaller, more frequent meals.

Patient Visit: 13 March 2024

Patient: Ive been experiencing some pain in my abdomen.

Doctor: Based on your symptoms and a recent CT scan, weve identified a CBD stone. We need to

refer you for an ERCP procedure to address this.

Follow-Up Visit: 5 April 2024

Patient: How is my condition now, Doctor?

Doctor: Youre showing improvements. Your liver function tests (LFTs) are better, and your bilirubin

levels  are  trending  down.  Your  diagnosis  is  still  HCV-related  DCLD  with  ascites,  and  you  had  the

obstructive  jaundice  due  to  the  choledocholithiasis.  The  stone  was  successfully  removed  through

the ERCP.

 Patient: Thats a relief. Whats next?

Doctor: Well stop the B-blocker due to your low blood pressure and stop the painkillers. I want you

to have LFTs every two weeks. Well follow up in 6 weeks to monitor your progress.

Follow-Up Visit: 3 June 2024

Patient: Doctor, Ive been feeling weak and lethargic.

Doctor:  Based  on  your  recent  CT  scan  from  March  2024,  theres  no  sign  of  HCC,  but  were  still

managing your chronic liver disease. We identified a large calculus in the distal end of the CBD. The

ERCP was successful in removing it.

Patient: Ive been on Spiromide, but Im still feeling tired.

Doctor: Given your symptoms, well stop Spiromide and start Lasix instead. Your recent lab results

show  some  improvement,  but  your  albumin  is  low  at  2.2.  We'll  repeat  your  LFTs  and  do  an  USG

abdomen. Youll need a follow-up in 3 months.

ImagingFindings: coarse liver with splenomegaly
multiple dilated veins at the splenic hilum
moderate ascites
thick gallbladder sludge with wall edema
cirrhotic liver
multiple upper abdominal collateral formations
large calculus in the distal end of the CBD

VisitTimeline.Details: First visit, discussed medical history and comorbidities.
Identified CBD stone, referred for ERCP.
Improvement noted, stone removed, adjustments to medications.
No sign of HCC, calculus removed, medication adjustments.

SummaryNarrative.ClinicalCourseProgression: Patient has chronic liver disease with a history of hepatitis C treatment and recent complications.
SummaryNarrative.DiagnosticJourney: Multiple imaging studies and lab tests conducted to monitor liver function and complications.
SummaryNarrative.TreatmentResponse: Patient showed improvement after ERCP and medication adjustments.
SummaryNarrative.OngoingConcerns: Continued monitoring of liver function and management of chronic conditions.

Patient:  Yes,  Ive  had  some  bleeding  per  rectum  due  to  hemorrhoids,  but  thats  been  an  ongoing

issue related to constipation.

Doctor: I see. Let me check your vitals. You seem stable for now. Your weight is 68 kg, and your

abdomen is soft, non-tender with an umbilical hernia.

Patient: Im concerned about my liver condition. Ive had ascites for the past month.

Doctor: I understand. Your last liver function tests were done on 14th February. Let me go over the

results:

Hemoglobin: 9

Platelets: 71,000

ALT: 29, AST: 42

 Bilirubin: 2.28

Albumin: 1.9

Creatinine: 0.7

Sodium: 139

Doctor:  Based  on  these  results,  your  liver  is  showing  signs  of  cirrhosis  and  ascites.  Weve  started

you  on  Velpaget  for  your  HCV  relapse,  and  well  monitor  your  progress  closely.  I  also  recommend

some medications for symptom management like spironolactone and omeprazole.

 continue  managing  your  ascites  with  diuretics.  Weve  already  discussed  potential  liver  transplant

options with your daughter, though her BMI is a bit high.

Patient: Yes, shes willing to be the donor.

Doctor:  Thats  great  to  hear.  Well  proceed  with  testing  her  blood  group  and  make  sure  shes  a

suitable donor. For now, lets continue your medications and manage your symptoms.

Date: 03/04/23

Doctor: How are you feeling today, Rehana?

Patient: Im still feeling weak, but theres no new pain or discomfort.

Doctor: Lets review your recent lab results:

Urea: 28

Creatinine: 0.9

Sodium: 122

Potassium: 5.6

Total Bilirubin: 1.7

Patient: My abdomen feels okay today. No signs of ascites.

Doctor:  Thats  good  to  hear.  Weve  scheduled  a  follow-up  in  two  weeks,  but  well  continue  your

medications for now. Lets also check on your hemorrhoids and consider a referral to a GI surgeon

for further treatment.

 Date: 18/04/23

Doctor:  Rehana,  your  recent  test  results  show  that  the  liver  transplant  is  the  best  option  for  you.

Your daughter is still interested in being a donor, although she has a BMI of 30.3.

Patient: Yes, shes willing, but Im a bit worried about the BMI issue.

Doctor:  Well  take  care  of  that.  Weve  also  referred  you  to  Dr.  Tauseef  for  the  next  steps  in  the

transplant process. The good news is your HCV has been under control. Youve been on DAAs, and

well continue the process based on your test results.

Date: 23/05/23

Doctor: Lets look at your recent results. How are you feeling today?

Patient: I feel a bit better, though still weak.

Doctor: The last EGD was done on 12/05 due to some melena, and it showed gastric erosions.

Patient: Ive had some abdominal discomfort.

Doctor:  Well  adjust  your  medications  accordingly.  Youll  continue  on  Movicol,  Surbex-Z,  and  other

supportive meds. Lets plan to repeat the CT scan and AFP in three months.

Date: 30/05/23

Doctor: How are you feeling today, Rehana?

Patient: I still feel some general weakness, and I have some discomfort in my abdomen.

Doctor: On examination, your abdomen is soft, non-tender, and not distended. Your liver condition

seems stable. Youve had mild ascites, but theres no need for tapping. I recommend continuing with

spironolactone, Movicol, and Surbex-Z. Well follow up in four weeks.

Date: 05/06/23

 Doctor: Lets discuss the next steps for your liver transplant. Your recent medical check-up is clear,

and your workup is complete. Your daughter remains a potential donor, but we will need to evaluate

her BMI further.

Patient: Yes, I understand. Im ready for the transplant process to move forward.

Doctor:  Well  continue  with  the  current  management  plan  and  schedule  a  follow-up  for  your

transplant date after your daughters exams.

Date: 26/07/23

Doctor: Rehana, its great to see you post-transplant. How have you been feeling?

Patient: Ive been feeling okay, but Im having shortness of breath and difficulty swallowing solid food.

Doctor: Well adjust your medications accordingly. Your liver biopsy shows no vascular invasion, and

your transplant seems to be progressing well. Well continue monitoring you closely.    27/11/2024

No prior surgeries

raw_text:
Gender: Female

Age: 43

MRN: 742428

Diagnosis: Chronic viral hepatitis C

History and Physical:

Patient: "Doctor, I had an open cholecystectomy and CBD exploration on June 24th, 2023, due to

cholelithiasis  and  Mirizzi  syndrome.  I  had  some  issues  with  an  infected  wound  and  drainage  after

the surgery."

Doctor: "Let me review your progress. How are you feeling now?"

Patient: "The wound has been infected, and theres been some pus discharge, but the doctor said its

improving."

Doctor: "I see. Your recent lab results showed that your liver function is still a bit off. Your ALT/AST

are elevated at 42/44, and your bilirubin is a bit high at 4.85. Have you had any significant weight

loss, fever, or cognitive limitations recently?"

Patient: "No weight loss, no fevers or night sweats. I feel okay aside from the abdominal pain."

Doctor:  "That's  good  to  hear.  Based  on  your  ultrasound  from  May  26,  2023,  it  shows  a  1.8  cm

calculus in the neck of the gallbladder and a dilated CBD. The MRCP also confirmed cholelithiasis

and cholestasis. How is your appetite?"

Patient: "Ive had some decreased appetite, but otherwise, Im okay."

 Doctor: "Well continue to monitor that. Ive reviewed your recent treatment plan. Were treating your

wound  infection  with  regular  wound  dressings,  antibiotics,  and  medications  like  Inj  Tanzo  and

Polyfax  ointment.  Ill  also  check  your  lab  results  from  July  10th  and  continue  with  the  follow-up  on

Friday."

Patient: "Okay, thank you, Doctor."

Follow-up Visit (September 7, 2023)

Patient:  "Doctor,  the  wound  is  still  healing,  but  theres  still  some  pain  and  tenderness  near  the

incision site."

Doctor: "On examination, your wound looks much better, but theres a slight sinus with minimal pus

discharge. Your lab results have shown a decrease in bilirubin and improved liver function compared

to your last visit. The ultrasound from September 18th shows mild splenomegaly and ascites, but no

major changes in the biliary system."

Patient: "What about my hepatitis C?"

Doctor: "Your PCR for hepatitis C was detected at 361,470 IU/ml in June, but well need to start your

treatment as soon as we can. Weve discussed Sofosbuvir and Velpatasvir, but I understand theres

some financial concern. Lets continue to manage your symptoms until we find a solution."

Follow-up Visit (October 13, 2023)

Patient:  "Doctor,  I've  been  feeling  some  upper  abdominal  pain  and  general  body  aches.  I've  also

had a fever for the last couple of days."

 Doctor: "Your CT scan from August 8th, 2023, showed no significant changes in liver conditions, but

theres  a  slight  concern  about  a  possible  bowel  injury  leading  to  an  enterocutaneous  fistula.  The

ultrasound  from  September  27th  was  reassuring,  showing  no  major  collections.  Well  continue  to

monitor your symptoms and adjust medications accordingly."

Follow-up Visit (December 7, 2023)

Patient: "Doctor, Ive been having chest pain and backache. It gets worse when I exert myself."

Doctor: "Its important that we rule out any heart-related issues. I'll refer you for a chest X-ray, ECG,

and Trop I levels to ensure theres no cardiac involvement. Well also follow up with an ultrasound to

check your abdomen and address any potential concerns with the biliary system."

Follow-up Visit (January 15, 2024)

Patient:  "Doctor,  I  started  taking  Sof/Dac  for  my  HCV  as  advised.  But  Im  still  experiencing  some

issues with my abdomen."

Doctor: "Thats good to hear about the treatment. Regarding your abdomen, your incision site seems

to have healed well, but theres still some tenderness in the right hypochondrium. Well keep an eye

on your recovery from the cholecystectomy and plan for any necessary surgical repairs."

Follow-up Visit (January 24, 2024)

Patient: "Doctor, Im still having pain in my epigastrium, and there's a swelling on the right side of my

abdomen."

 Doctor: "On examination, I found a 2 cm defect in the right hypochondrium. It looks like an incisional

hernia.  Im  referring  you  for  pre-op  anesthesia  assessment  and  a  consultation  for  mesh  repair

surgery. Well proceed with scheduling the surgery as soon as possible."

Patient Summary:

Diagnoses:

HCV (treatment-naive)

Mirizzi Syndrome (post-op)

Post-operative infection with wound ulceration

Recent Treatment:

Sofosbuvir/Daclatasvir (for HCV)

ERCP (multiple, with stent placements)

Wound care (dressings, antibiotics)

Surgery consultation for incisional hernia

Recent Tests:

PCR (HCV), Ultrasound Abdomen, CT Scan Abdomen

 Lab results show improvement in liver function with some residual concerns

Plan:

Continue monitoring liver function

Wound healing, stent management, and hernia surgery scheduled

Referral for further diagnostic tests (chest X-ray, ECG)

ActiveSymptoms: Swelling on right side of abdomen

DiagnosticConclusions: Possible bowel injury leading to enterocutaneous fistula

ImagingFindings: Ultrasound Abdomen
CT Scan Abdomen
LabResults: PCR for hepatitis C detected at 361,470 IU/ml

VisitTimeline: June 24, 2023: Open cholecystectomy and CBD exploration

SummaryNarrative.ClinicalCourseProgression: Patient has undergone surgery for cholelithiasis and Mirizzi syndrome, with subsequent wound infection and ongoing abdominal issues.
SummaryNarrative.DiagnosticJourney: Multiple imaging studies and lab tests conducted to monitor liver function and assess post-operative complications.
SummaryNarrative.TreatmentResponse: Patient started on Sofosbuvir/Daclatasvir for HCV, with ongoing management of wound healing and abdominal symptoms.
SummaryNarrative.OngoingConcerns: Continued abdominal pain, potential incisional hernia, and need for further evaluation of chest pain.

raw_text:
Gender: Male

Age: 5

MRN: 867175

Diagnosis: Budd-Chiari syndrome

History and Physical:

Patient: Ive been feeling a lot of abdominal distention again, doctor. It's causing a lot of discomfort.

Doctor: I see. Can you tell me a bit more about how long you've been experiencing this issue?

Patient: It started around 3 years ago, along with a fever. At first, I was treated for abdominal TB at a

local  hospital  for  about  a  year.  After  that,  I  was  okay  for  two  years,  but  then  the  same

symptomsfever  and  abdominal  distentioncame  back.  I  saw  Dr.  Nagina  Shahzadi  who  gave  me

antibiotics, but things didnt improve much, so I was referred to Childrens Hospital Lahore for further

treatment.

Doctor: And what happened at Childrens Hospital?

Patient: I was admitted for about 15 days, and after several investigations, they diagnosed me with

Budd  Chiari  Syndrome  based  on  a  CT  scan  and  ultrasound  of  my  abdomen.  They  also  had  to  do

multiple taps during my stay.

Doctor: Got it. Have you experienced any decompensations since then?

Patient: Yes, Ive had jaundice and ascites.

Doctor:  I  understand.  Let  me  check  your  previous  medical  history...  You  mentioned  a  history  of

abdominal TB. Can you tell me more about that?

 Patient: I had treatment for abdominal TB for a year in Aziz Fatima Hospital. After that, I was stable

for about two years before the symptoms returned.

Doctor: Okay, thank you for that information. Let me now check your current examination findings.

Youve been showing signs of jaundice, pallor, and edema up to your ankles, correct?

Patient: Yes, thats right. Ive also had some difficulty breathing and Ive been feeling really tired.

Doctor: I see that your physical exam shows hepatomegaly, prominent veins, and mild to moderate

ascites. Well need to closely monitor your liver function and ascites management.

Patient:  Ive  been  following  my  medications,  as  advised.  Im  currently  on  Syrup  Paracetamol,

Lasoride, Aldactone, and a few others. Is this still the right treatment for me?

Doctor: Yes, your current medications seem appropriate for managing the condition. However, well

need to make some adjustments based on the latest lab results and radiological findings. Let me go

over those with you.

Doctor: Your recent lab results show that your bilirubin is 2.3, AST is 125, albumin is low at 2.2, and

your INR is elevated at 2.2. These all suggest liver dysfunction, and we need to continue managing

those with medications like albumin replacement. Your hemoglobin is also quite low at 8.4, and your

platelet count is 78, so we need to monitor for any bleeding risks.

Patient: I see. Is there anything else I need to be concerned about?

Doctor: Your livers condition is quite concerning, and I also want to highlight the findings from your

 recent radiological scans. Your ultrasound shows liver enlargement with hypertrophy of the caudate

lobe.  The  CT  scan  shows  signs  of  hepatomegaly,  with  a  narrowed  intrahepatic  IVC  and  features

consistent with Budd Chiari Syndrome.

Patient: Whats the plan moving forward?

Doctor:  Well  continue  your  medications,  but  we  are  considering  a  liver  transplant  as  the  definitive

treatment.  Well  discuss  this  in  our  multidisciplinary  team  (MDT)  meeting.  In  the  meantime,  well

discontinue the diuretics, monitor your lab results closely, and plan for an endoscopy to assess any

other potential issues.

Patient: That sounds serious. What do I need to do at home?

Doctor:  Youll  need  to  continue  your  current  medications  and  make  sure  you  follow  up  with  the

scheduled labs. We also recommend some additional support, such as taking Vitamin A, D, and E

drops,  and  ensuring  you're  on  the  MCT  oil  regimen.  Ill  also  prescribe  some  antibiotics  in  case  of

infection.

Patient: Thank you for explaining everything, doctor. Im a bit worried, but Ill follow your instructions

closely.

Doctor: I understand this is a lot to take in. We will be here every step of the way, and well ensure

you get the best care possible. Lets stay in touch and monitor your progress closely. Do you have

any other questions or concerns?

Patient: Not at the moment. Ill follow up as you suggested. Thank you.

 Impression: Budd Chiari Syndrome

Plan:

Discuss in MDT

Discontinue diuretics (Tablet Lasoride, Aldactone)

Follow up on Friday

Repeat baseline labs on follow-up

Screening endoscopy planned

Continue current medications

Parental counseling done

ImagingFindings: CT scan shows signs of hepatomegaly
narrowed intrahepatic IVC
ultrasound shows liver enlargement with hypertrophy of the caudate lobe

VisitTimeline: admitted for about 15 days at Childrens Hospital
treatment for abdominal TB for a year

SummaryNarrative.ClinicalCourseProgression: Patient experienced abdominal distention and fever for 3 years, treated for abdominal TB, stable for 2 years, then symptoms returned.
SummaryNarrative.DiagnosticJourney: Diagnosed with Budd-Chiari syndrome after investigations at Childrens Hospital.
SummaryNarrative.TreatmentResponse: Current medications are appropriate, but adjustments may be needed based on lab results.
SummaryNarrative.OngoingConcerns: Monitoring liver function and managing ascites, considering liver transplant.
